<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.

<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_IdleLoop_Impl:
```c
void OS_IdleLoop_Impl(void)
{
    /*
     * Unblock signals and wait for something to occur
     *
     * Note - "NormalSigMask" was calculated during task init to be the original signal mask
     * of the process PLUS all "RT" signals.  The RT signals are used by timers, so we want
     * to keep them masked here (this is different than the original POSIX impl).  The
     * timebase objects have a dedicated thread that will be doing "sigwait" on those.
     */
    sigsuspend(&POSIX_GlobalVars.NormalSigMask);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameters are declared in OS_IdleLoop_Impl (signature: void OS_IdleLoop_Impl(void)), so there are no parameters that could be modified within this function. The only notable statement is the call sigsuspend(&POSIX_GlobalVars.NormalSigMask); which passes the address of a global sigset object. This does not modify any parameter of OS_IdleLoop_Impl. Moreover, the POSIX prototype for sigsuspend takes a const sigset_t * (i.e. sigsuspend(const sigset_t *mask)), so the callee is not expected to modify the pointed-to object via the pointer, and any modification of a pointer parameter inside a callee would be local to that function (the pointer is passed by value). Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that need to be investigated for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
